awd_titl_txt: CSR: Medium: Collaborative Research: Foundations of Cache Network Operations for Content Delivery
awd_abstract_narration:
When a user goes online to read the news, watch videos, buy products, play games, or use a social network, the content accessed by the user is delivered to his/her device by a large Internet-scale network called a content delivery network (CDN). A CDN may consist of hundreds of thousands of servers located in thousands of data centers around the world. Operating a large CDN is challenging due to the sheer scale and diversity of the traffic and due to the vastness of their distributed server infrastructure. This research focuses on enabling highly efficient CDN operations.

The key goals of this project are minimizing the operating cost and maximizing the robustness of the network. This project develops techniques for mapping different traffic classes to servers, so as to optimize resource usage, increase hit rates, and lower bandwidth costs.  This project also develops adaptive and self-tuning systems that are robust to common sources of CDN variability, including object popularity/size, load, latency, and availability. Since CDNs are the key infrastructure enabling  web, video, and other online applications,  this project has a significant positive impact on the quality-of-experience of Internet users, while lowering the cost of Internet services.

The project will broaden participation by involving undergraduates in the research. Further, the project will help attract women to Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) careers through outreach activities, including "Tech Nights" and "Roadshows" for middle school girls, and including semi-annual "Career Advice talks"  to students from high school through grad school. The project will also incorporate topics in large-scale network operations in the curriculum. Finally, the project will invest significantly in outreach and tech transfer to the CDN industry by incorporating our research in production systems and enabling students to gain real-world experience in the CDN industry through internships.

All products of the project, including research papers, software, and data, will be made available to the public. In particular, the software and data produced by the project will be archived for at least five years, and even longer when feasible. There will be two software and data repositories: one at UMass Amherst (https://www.cs.umass.edu/~ramesh/Site/CODE_DATA.html) and the other at CMU (http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~harchol/SoftwareDataRepository.html).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) are large distributed systems consisting of servers deployed in thousands of data centers worldwide. They are the critical infrastructure that underlie the functioning of the global internet, delivering web pages, videos, and applications to billions of users worldwide. Our project focused on two critical goals of CDN operations: minimizing operating costs and maximizing the network's robustness and performance. 

Intellectual Merit: To achieve the twin goals, our project made the following significant contributions. 

1) Novel methods for caching content.

The functioning of a CDN relies on caching content, such as web pages and videos, in hundreds of thousands of edge servers. These servers store the most popular content and serve them to the users nearby in a manner that is fast, reliable, and economical. A significant part of the operating expenses (OPEX) of a CDN is the bandwidth cost of moving content from its point of origin to the edge servers of the CDN. Our work proposed a traffic model called footprint descriptors and used it to minimize the bandwidth cost. Further, a CDN must be resilient when one or more of its servers fail.  Our work devised novel schemes that use erasure codes to cache content fragments in multiple servers so that the content can be recovered even if some servers fail. Finally, we worked on the problem of request routing, the process that users use to connect to a nearby CDN cache. Our work showed how to optimize the commonly-used ip anycast technique for orchestrating the request routing process.

2) Using Machine Learning to enhance caching operations (ML-for-CDN).

The caches in a CDN serve varying types of traffic, including videos, web pages, software downloads, games, and applications. Machine Learning (ML) is a tool that can be effectively used to learn and adapt the caching strategy to traffic patterns. Our RLCache system explored reinforcement learning to decide which content is unlikely to be accessed in the near future and so can be evicted from the cache. In our Darwin caching system, we use an alternate approach. We deployed a set of caching algorithms called experts and used ML to pick the expert that performs the best for the current traffic conditions. In these works, we made significant advances in the creation of caching systems that automatically learn to adapt to their traffic characteristics that vary with time and location. 

3) Using CDNs to power Machine Learning Inference (CDN-for-ML).

ML inference is increasing a part of the content and applications users access worldwide. To serve ML inferences at a large scale to billions of users, the edge servers would need to host and serve ML models with low cost and high performance. Our Proteus and Loki systems manage resources for hosting ML models within a CDN edge cluster to optimize cost and performance. A key idea to emerge from our work is the concept of accuracy scaling, where the accuracy of the ML inference can be varied to accommodate increased user query demand. 

4) Synthetic Trace Generation for CDN cache simulations.

A perennial problem in CDN caching research is the lack of production traces available to the public, such traces are essential to simulate and develop new caching protocols. The dearth of publically-available CDN traces stem from the fact that traces from production caches are proprietary to the commercial CDN that deployed those caches. To alleviate the problem, we used our footprint descriptor traffic model that captures the essential access characteristics of diverse traffic classes, such as videos, software downloads, web pages, images, etc. We built two synthetic trace generators, Tragen and Jedi, that can take the footprint descriptor model of a traffic class and generate synthetic traces that are provably similar to actual production traces for that class. In particular, we show that cache simulations using the synthetic traces produces nearly the same results as simulations using production traces. We made our trace generators and the accompanying footprint descriptor models available to the research community, allowing them to generate realistic traces for their own research. 

Broader Impacts:

In addition to the specific research contributions listed above, our work has had significant broader impacts. Several graduate students were trained as part of this grant and have gone on to contribute their expertise to leading CDN and cloud service providers in industry. Our work on synthetic trace generation has also been used by other scientists to advance their caching research. Notably, our trace generation tool Tragen also won the ACM IMC Community Contribution Award. Finally, footprint descriptors and their use in cache resource management has gained some traction and is used in the CDN industry..
